result.execSummary:
Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Sierra Gartmann

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt:
Clerk Marisa.
Case Called: 3:57 pm 
INCLUDES 15CM1522 AND 15CM1690. 
State appears by ADA Kerri Puig; Def appears in person, pro se. 
VRCW. 

State moves to: 
In 15CM1522: Ct. 2 (Resisting or Obstructing an Officer)>>D&RI. 
In 15CM1690: Ct. 1 (DC)>>D&RI. 
                       : Ct. 2 (Misd. BJ)>>D&RI. 
COURT grants above. 

PLEA: In 15CM1522: Ct. 1 (DC)>>GUILTY. 

COURT advises def of rights (including constitutional rights) & penalties & ques def to understanding.  
COURT finds plea & waiver of rights freely & vol made, def is competent to represent self, a factual basis, & def guilty. 
Def makes statement. 

COURT ORDERS: $50 plus costs; DNA sample and surcharge. 
COURT finds the def eligible to petition for expungement any time after costs and fine has been paid. 

Adj: 4:09 pm

No contact with victim(s):  R.B.  Contact includes direct personal or physical and indirect contact by phone, in writing of any kind, entry to the person's residence or place of employment together with contacts through other persons.  Contact, however, may be made through the defendant's attorney.
